text: Anyone here has a good forum post/ tutorial here to find duplicated protein sequences in a fasta using Julia?

elements.text: Anyone here has a good forum post/ tutorial here to find duplicated protein sequences in a fasta using Julia?

text: Or is that a bad idea? :grin:

elements.text: Or is that a bad idea?

text: What would be a good approach. E.g. Read in the fasta and store everything in a dictionary?

elements.text: What would be a good approach. E.g. Read in the fasta and store everything in a dictionary?

text: Should be pretty easy. Yeah, exactly that. Maybe use a Set instead of a Dict. Make absolutely sure not to mutate any of the sequences you have in your set/dict

elements.text: Should be pretty easy. Yeah, exactly that. Maybe use a Set instead of a Dict. Make absolutely sure not to mutate any of the sequences you have in your set/dict

text:
maybe something like
```open(FASTA.Reader, "my_file") do reader
    d = Dict{LongAminoAcidSeq, FASTA.Record}()
    foreach(reader) do record
        d[FASTA.sequence(LongAminoAcidSeq, record)] = record
    end
    collect(values(d))
end```
Not optimially efficient, but should be OK

end
Not optimially efficient, but should be OK

text: That is cool! I'll give it a shot starting with that :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: That is cool! I'll give it a shot starting with that

text: Why did you go for a Dictionary instead of a set though?

elements.text: Why did you go for a Dictionary instead of a set though?

text: In order to extract the whole records, including the headers, instead of just the unique sequences

elements.text: In order to extract the whole records, including the headers, instead of just the unique sequences
Of course!

text: I don't know if that's what you want though

elements.text: I don't know if that's what you want though

text: Yes! In the end, I need to know which seqs have been duplicated... So the keys are important to have

elements.text: Yes! In the end, I need to know which seqs have been duplicated... So the keys are important to have

text:
That worked great! Ended up using identifier only instead of record as value.

```    # Create empty dictionary
    d = Dict{LongAminoAcidSeq, String}()

    open(FASTA.Reader, fasta_file) do reader
        foreach(reader) do record
            d[FASTA.sequence(LongAminoAcidSeq, record)] = FASTX.identifier(record)
        end
        collect(values(d))
    end```

elements.text: That worked great! Ended up using identifier only instead of record as value.

# Create empty dictionary
    d = Dict{LongAminoAcidSeq, String}()

    open(FASTA.Reader, fasta_file) do reader
        foreach(reader) do record
            d[FASTA.sequence(LongAminoAcidSeq, record)] = FASTX.identifier(record)
        end
        collect(values(d))
    end

text: Only one question, what exactly does the collect do? It merges multiple values?

elements.text: Only one question, what exactly does the collect do? It merges multiple values?

text: It turns an iterable into an array

elements.text: It turns an iterable into an array

text:
Okay I get it! I first thought that in the above script all values belonging to the same key would have been stored, but they are just overwritten right?

So you end up with a reduced set already where the last sequence in the fasta file is kept, if a duplication occured
